titleStmt.title: Animating Multidimensional Scaling t o Visualize N-Dimensional Data Sets

analytic.title: Animating Multidimensional Scaling t o Visualize N-Dimensional Data Sets

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Many techniques have been developed for visualizing multivariate (multidimensional) data. Most, if not all, are limited by the number of dimensions which can be effectively displayed. Multidimensional Scaling (MDS) is an iterative non-linear technique for projecting n-D data down to a lower number of dimensions. This work presents extensions to MDS that enhance visualization of high-dimensional data sets. These extensions include animation, stochastic perturbation, and flow visualization techniques.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: There are four general approaches to visually presenting high dimensional data: 1) use multiple views of the data, each communicating a subset of the dimensions (e.g. scatterplot matrices [5]); 2) rearrange the axes to be non-orthogonal and display data along all axes simultaneously, such as in parallel coordinates [3] and glyphs/icons [2]; 3) embed or combine data dimensions to form composite spatial dimensions, such as in dimensional stacking [ 5 ] ; 4) reduce the dimensionality (e.g. statistical techniques) to two or three dimensions.

Each method results in the distortion of the ndimensional relationships between data points in order to map the data to the display. However, dimensionality reduction techniques explicitly attempt t o preserve these relationships. The focus of our research is on dimensional reduction, and specifically on extensions to the Multidimensional Scaling (MDS) process. MDS is a non-linear method for projecting n-D data down to a reduced number of dimensions [4]

div.head: Extensions to MDS
div.p: Previous studies of using MDS for displaying n-D data have generated a single "low stress" configuration of display points [l]. Unfortunately, as the dimensionality of the data increases, the final computed configuration may still have local regions of high stress (a standard problem with global optimization techniques). In order to enhance the effectiveness of MDS for displaying high dimensional data, we are investigating the animation of the optimization process, with added random perturbations to the display point positions to prevent getting "stuck" in a sub-optimal configuration (as in simulated annealing). The user may then observe multiple good configurations, rather than a single view. Intermediate frames showing localized low stress regions provide additional insights into the data.

A simple example of a situation for which no single low-stress configuration exists is shown in Figure 1, which contains 4 points with equal interpoint similarities (a unit 3-D tetrahedron) projected onto a plane. The global optimal cannot portray this configuration of similarities accurately. However, the trace of the point positions over time clearly shows oscillation over a range of acceptable positions.

Another method for preventing MDS from getting stuck in a local minimum is to exaggerate the displacement of points as they are updated. Enlarging the step size will cause points to overshoot their optimal low stress position, thus forcing corrections to their position on the next iteration. This may lead to points potentially oscillating around several low stress "attractors,'' illuminating more about the forces acting on these points. To compensate for problems monitoring point motion, intermediate frames are generated with spline-fitted point positions.

div.head: Results and Conclusions
div.p: We have developed a program, MAVIS, that implements several extensions to the traditional MDS algorithm. In particular MAVIS has the following ca- Early experiments suggest that animating MDS and adding random perturbations has significant potential for improving the visualization of high dimensional data. Color coding each display point based on stress lets the user monitor high or low stress regions. For example, in Figure 2, the areas of high and low stress within each cluster varies over time. By coloring high stress points red so that they intuitively stand out and letting the animated trace accumulate, the areas which are persistently subject to high stress will stand out even when visualizing large numbers of points. This may prove an effective means of approaching the visualization of large data sets having high dimensionality.
